Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predicting Single Cell Mechanical Behavior: Integrated Insight of Mechanical Theory and Microfluidic Device Experiments

The mechanics of single cells, or how cells deform and respond to forces from the surrounding environment, is important both for understanding fundamental cellular biology and diagnosing and treating diseases. For example, red blood cells are less deformable and stiffer when infected by malaria. Vesicles, simpler enclosures made of lipid (fatty) molecule bilayers, can be used as simple models of living cells. Vesicles also have their own biologically inspired applications in green energy technology, biosensor technology, and targeted drug delivery. This project brings together the integrated insight of novel microfluidic devices and rigorous mechanical theory from engineering to investigate single vesicle and cell mechanical behavior. By observing cell deformation under well-controlled flow conditions and simultaneously shaping a theory to explain the observations, a predictive cell mechanics simulation tool will be developed. This project will improve understanding of (1) the response of synthetic vesicles and natural cells to a range of external flows from pure rotational to pure extensional flows, (2) the impact of membrane molecular structure on vesicle and cell mechanics and how theory can capture this effect, and (3) the adaptation of this microfluidic device and accompanying theory to a high-throughput method for studying single cell mechanics in biological research.

Broader impacts of this research include advancing understanding in fundamental cell mechanics while also promoting teaching and learning through the training and mentorship of undergraduate researchers and participation in K-12 outreach programs. The fellow will gain experience and training in cellular biology to complement a mechanical engineering background, spurring on a multi-disciplinary research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Single Cell Mechanical Behavior: Integrated Insight of Mechanical Theory and Microfluidic Device Experiments

Joanna B. Dahl 

 

A fundamental challenge in biology and medicine is that variety exists even within a single cell type. This means that valuable information is lost in conventional experimental techniques that report average measurements of the cell population and that drugs are only effective treating certain cancer cells and not universally successful for all patients. Understanding the characteristics of individual cells and the range of variability will ultimately help us identify the best assortment of cancer cell characteristics to target with drugs in order to successfully treat cancer in every patient. This project investigated the mechanics of single cells, or how cell deform and respond to forces from the surrounding environment. Cell mechanics is important both for understanding the basics of cell function and diagnosing and treating diseases. For example, a rare subtype of brain cancer cells are responsible for starting new tumors, and it is thought that these tumor-initiating cells are effective at starting new tumors in part because they are softer and can more easily migrate through the brain to a new location. This project brings together the integrated insight of microfluidic devices, micron-scale channels particularly good at analyzing cells one at a time, and rigorous mechanical theory from engineering to quantitatively measurements and analyze cell mechanical behavior. 

 

We first studied cell-mimics called vesicles that are composed of only the lipid bilayer component of a cell membrane and approximate red blood cell behavior in fluid flow. Studying the deformation and stability of vesicles in extensional, stretching flow improves our understanding of cell damage for medical applications such red blood cell rupture in medical devices and artificial organs. In a collaborative effort between Berkeley and Stanford research groups, we performed the first experimental observations of vesicle break-up in extensional flow and our measurements were consistent with the Stanford group’s theoretical and computer simulation predictions. Thus, in some sense, we experimentally discovered conditions under which cell-like objects will ‘mechanically fail,’ which would be important for various applications such as drug delivery, blood flow in artificial organs, or any biomedical applications in which suspended cells experience stretching.

 

Next we progressed to measuring the stiffness of suspended living cells with the same microfluidic trapping and stretching device. We developed an analytical mechanical model to measure cell stiffness from the observed stretching for rapid, single-cell measurements. Our technique detected the expected cell mechanics changes due to drug treatments: we measured a significant change in cell stiffness after treatment with drugs known to soften and stiffen cell. Our microfluidic device is a simple, high-throughput measurement technique that can be used by biologists and physicists to measure the stiffness of microscale, deformable objects and compare with other groups and other experiments.

 

Broader impacts of this research include promoting teaching and learning through the training and mentorship of an undergraduate researcher and elementary school outreach. The fellow mentored an undergraduate researcher, whose important contributions entitled him to inclusion as an author in an upcoming research article.
